realworld.description: Banks use complex compound interest formulas to determine Equated Monthly Installments (EMI) for home and car loans.

notes.title: Problem Solving Strategy
points: Always translate the word problem into a linear equation. Assume the present age to be 'x'.
If 'n' years ago, then age was (x - n). If 'n' years hence, then age will be (x + n).
Ratio of ages: If the ratio of A and B is p:q, their ages can be taken as px and qx.
The difference between two people's ages remains constant throughout their lives.

formulas.title: Age Ratio Change
formulas.explanation: The standard setup for problems where the ratio of two people's ages changes after a certain number of years.

realworld.title: Insurance Underwriting
realworld.description: Insurance officers calculate 'age hence' to determine maturity periods and premiums for life insurance policies.

notes.title: Commercial Mathematics
points: Profit = SP - CP; Loss = CP - SP. Profit/Loss % is always calculated on CP unless stated otherwise.
Marked Price (MP) is the price on the tag. Discount is always calculated on MP.
Successive Discounts: If d1 and d2 are two discounts, Net Discount = [d1 + d2 - (d1*d2/100)] %.
Dishonest Dealer concept: Profit occurs by using less weight or marking up the price.

formulas.title: SP with Profit/Loss
formulas.explanation: Used to find the selling price value given the cost price and a target profit or loss percentage.

realworld.title: Retail Banking
realworld.description: Banks analyze the 'Profit and Loss' of specific branches to decide on closures, expansions, or operational efficiency improvements.

notes.title: Pattern Recognition
points: Common patterns include: Difference, Double Difference, Squares/Cubes, Prime numbers, and Geometric series.
Missing Number Series: Find the value that completes the logic.
Wrong Number Series: Identify the one term that breaks the established pattern (often considered harder).
Watch for 'Mixed' series where two different operations alternate (e.g., +2, *3, +2, *3).

formulas.title: Arithmetic Progression (AP)
formulas.explanation: Used to solve series where the difference between consecutive terms is constant.

realworld.title: Trend Forecasting
realworld.description: Analysts look at series of transaction counts or customer footfalls to predict future growth trends in digital banking.

notes.title: Motion Concepts
points: 1 km/hr = 5/18 m/sec; 1 m/sec = 18/5 km/hr. Knowing this conversion is vital for IBPS questions.
Relative Speed: If two objects move in same direction, speed = S1 - S2. If opposite direction, speed = S1 + S2.
Trains: When a train crosses a pole/man, distance = length of train. When it crosses a platform, distance = train length + platform length.
Boats and Streams: Downstream speed = u + v; Upstream speed = u - v (where u is boat speed, v is stream speed).

formulas.title: Distance Formula
formulas.explanation: The core relationship between motion variables; always ensure units are consistent (km with hours, meters with seconds).

realworld.title: Logistics Financing
realworld.description: Banks financing trucking fleets analyze speed and time data to verify the operational efficiency and revenue potential of the business.

notes.title: Work Efficiency
points: Work Done = Time * Efficiency. If person A completes work in 'X' days, A's 1-day work is 1/X.
Efficiency and Time are inversely proportional: more efficiency means less time taken.
Pipes and Cisterns: Similar to time and work. Inlet pipes do positive work, outlet/leak pipes do negative work.
Man-Days: M1 * D1 * H1 / W1 = M2 * D2 * H2 / W2 (The chain rule).

formulas.title: Joint Work Formula
formulas.explanation: To find the total time taken when multiple individuals or machines work together on a single task.

realworld.title: Operational Management
realworld.description: Bank operations managers use time and work concepts to determine the number of staff required at the cash counter during peak hours.

notes.title: Arithmetic Foundations
points: Understand types of numbers: Natural, Whole, Integers, Prime, Composite, and Rational/Irrational.
Divisibility Rules for 2, 3, 4, 5, 8, 9, 11 are crucial for fast cancellation in large sums.
Unit Digit concept: Find the last digit of large powers (e.g., 7^105) using cyclicity (for 7 it is 4).
Factorial Properties and Remainders (using Euler's theorem or Fermat's Little Theorem for advanced sets).

formulas.title: Sum of Pows/Serials
formulas.formula: Sum of first 'n' natural nos = n(n+1)/2; Sum of squares = n(n+1)(2n+1)/6
formulas.explanation: Useful for solving series-based problems and large arithmetic summations.

realworld.title: Data Encryption
realworld.description: Secure banking transactions rely on RSA encryption, which uses the properties of very large prime numbers and the number system.

notes.title: Quantitative Precision
points: Determine if a unique numerical value can be calculated from the given data.
Check for variables: If you have two unknown variables, you generally need two independent equations.
Be careful with quadratic results: if an equation gives two possible values, the statement might not be sufficient if a single answer is required.
Common topics: Ratio, Average, Interest, and Geometry sufficiency.

formulas.title: Variable Rule
formulas.explanation: The fundamental mathematical requirement to find unique values for a set of unknowns.

realworld.title: Investment Valuation
realworld.description: Financial analysts evaluate if enough market data is available to accurately calculate the Fair Market Value (FMV) of a company.

notes.title: System of Equations
points: Linear equations in one variable (ax + b = 0) and two variables (ax + by = c).
Methods of solving: Substitution, Elimination, or Cross-Multiplication.
Word problems: Translating conditions into equations (e.g., 'A is twice as old as B' becomes A=2B).
Check for 'Infinite solutions' or 'No solutions' in mains-level coordinate geometry problems.

formulas.title: Equation of Line
formulas.explanation: Used to describe linear relationships where 'm' is the slope (rate of change) and 'c' is the intercept.

realworld.title: Budgeting
realworld.description: Businesses use linear equations to calculate the total cost by summing fixed overheads and variable costs per unit produced.

notes.title: Counting Principles
points: Permutation (P) is for 'Arrangement' where order matters (e.g., forming a 3-digit number).
Combination (C) is for 'Selection' where order does not matter (e.g., selecting a committee).
Circular Permutation: If 'n' objects are arranged in a circle, total arrangements = (n-1)!.
If items must be together: Bundle them as one item and then arrange internally.

formulas.title: P and C Formulas
formulas.explanation: Primary formulas for calculating the total number of ways to arrange or select groups of items.

realworld.title: Security Systems
realworld.description: Bank security analysts use permutations to calculate the total possible combinations of a 6-digit ATM PIN to assess vulnerability to brute-force attacks.

notes.title: Likelihood Theory
points: Probability of an event P(E) = Number of favorable outcomes / Total number of possible outcomes.
The value of probability always lies between 0 and 1 inclusive. Sum of P(Occurrence) + P(Non-occurrence) = 1.
Independent Events: P(A ∩ B) = P(A) * P(B).
Common types: Dice problems, Card problems (52 deck), and Ball selection from bags.

formulas.title: Combination Probability
formulas.explanation: Where n(E) is the number of ways the event can happen and n(S) is the total number of outcomes in the sample space.

realworld.title: Credit Scoring
realworld.description: Banks assign a 'Probability of Default' (PD) score to borrowers based on historical data to decide whether to approve a loan.

notes.title: Web Technologies
points: Internet is a global network of computers; WWW is a service on it using HTTP/HTTPS.
E-mail protocols: SMTP (Send), POP3/IMAP (Receive). IBPS often asks about these ports.
Search Engines vs. Browsers: Google is a search engine; Chrome is a browser.
Cloud Computing: SaaS, PaaS, and IaaS models are increasingly relevant for modern banking.

notes.title: Cyber Security & Protocols
points: Firewalls: Act as a barrier between internal trusted networks and untrusted external ones like the Internet.
Phishing: Fraudulent attempts to obtain sensitive info by masquerading as a trustworthy entity.
Cookies: Small pieces of data sent from a website and stored on the user's computer to track history.
SSL/TLS: Protocols that provide communication security over a computer network.

formulas.title: Data Speed
formulas.formula: 1 Byte = 8 bits; 1 Kbps = 1000 bits per second
formulas.explanation: Essential for understanding bandwidth and transaction processing speeds in digital banking.

formulas.title: Network Latency
formulas.formula: Total Delay = Propagation + Transmission + Queuing + Processing
formulas.explanation: Calculates the total time it takes for data to travel from source to destination across a network.

realworld.title: Online Banking
realworld.description: The 's' in HTTPS (SSL/TLS) ensures that customer data is encrypted before being sent over the internet to the bank server.

realworld.title: VPN Tunnels
realworld.description: Bank employees use Virtual Private Networks (VPNs) to securely access internal systems from branch offices or home.

notes.title: Storage Hierarchy
points: Primary Memory: RAM (Volatile) and ROM (Non-volatile). Cache is the fastest primary memory.
Secondary Memory: HDD, SSD, Magnetic Tapes, and Optical Discs for long-term storage.
Register Memory is the small, high-speed storage inside the CPU.
Virtual Memory: Use of secondary storage to simulate additional RAM.

notes.title: RAM Types & Cache
points: SRAM (Static RAM): Faster and used for Cache; DRAM (Dynamic RAM): Used as main system memory.
L1, L2, L3 Cache: Levels of high-speed memory integrated into or near the CPU.
Flash Memory: Non-volatile storage used in SSDs and USB drives, bridging the gap between RAM and HDD.
Storage Lifetime: SSDs have limited write cycles compared to HDDs but offer vastly superior speeds.

formulas.title: Storage Units
formulas.explanation: Standard binary storage measurements used to specify server and database capacities.

formulas.title: Memory Access Time
formulas.explanation: Formula for effective access time where 'h' is hit ratio, 'C' is cache access time, and 'M' is main memory access time.

realworld.title: Core Banking Systems
realworld.description: Banks use high-speed SSDs for 'In-Memory' databases to process millions of transactions per second with minimal latency.

realworld.title: Transaction Logging
realworld.description: Critical database logs are stored on RAID-configured hard drives to ensure zero data loss during power failures.

notes.title: Windows & MS Office
points: Ctrl+C (Copy), Ctrl+V (Paste), Ctrl+X (Cut), Ctrl+Z (Undo), Ctrl+Y (Redo).
Alt+Tab: Switch between open programs. Win+D: Show Desktop.
MS Excel: F2 (Edit cell), Ctrl+; (Insert current date), Ctrl+Shift+: (Insert current time).
Chrome: Ctrl+T (New tab), Ctrl+Shift+T (Reopen closed tab).

notes.title: Formatting & System Keys
points: Ctrl+B (Bold), Ctrl+I (Italic), Ctrl+U (Underline) in document editors.
Alt+F4: Close the active item, or exit the active app.
Shift+Delete: Permanently delete the selected item without moving it to the Recycle Bin.
Win+L: Lock your PC or switch accounts instantly.

formulas.title: Shortcut Logic
formulas.explanation: The standard way to access menu commands without using a mouse in Windows applications.

formulas.title: Control Sequencing
formulas.explanation: Logical mapping where the Control key modifies a character key to execute a predefined software command.

realworld.title: Operational Efficiency
realworld.description: Bank tellers use keyboard shortcuts to quickly navigate banking software, reducing customer wait times at the counter.

realworld.title: Data Cleansing
realworld.description: Back-office staff use Excel shortcuts like Ctrl+Shift+L (Filters) and Ctrl+PageDown to navigate massive audit spreadsheets rapidly.

notes.title: Common Acronyms
points: BIOS: Basic Input/Output System; GUI: Graphical User Interface.
ALU: Arithmetic Logic Unit; CU: Control Unit.
URL: Uniform Resource Locator; IP: Internet Protocol.
ASCII: American Standard Code for Information Interchange.

notes.title: Advanced Abbreviations
points: JSON: JavaScript Object Notation; XML: eXtensible Markup Language.
SaaS: Software as a Service; VPN: Virtual Private Network.
SQL: Structured Query Language; ODBC: Open Database Connectivity.
REST: Representational State Transfer (common for modern web APIs).

formulas.title: Encoding Formula
formulas.explanation: Where 'n' is the number of bits; e.g., ASCII uses 7 or 8 bits to represent characters.

formulas.title: Data Compression
formulas.explanation: Measures the efficiency of formats like ZIP or JPEG in reducing digital footprint.

realworld.title: Tech Support
realworld.description: Bank IT departments use abbreviations for quick communication when troubleshooting system errors or network outages.

realworld.title: API Documentation
realworld.description: Banks share API (Application Programming Interface) docs formatted in JSON to allow third-party apps to process insurance or UPI payments.

notes.title: Office Productivity
points: Word: Focus on Mail Merge, Macros, and formatting tools for report generation.
Excel: Essential formulas (SUM, AVERAGE, VLOOKUP, Pivot Tables) for data analysis.
PowerPoint: Slide Master and animation tools for professional presentations.
Outlook: Managing emails, calendars, and tasks in a corporate setting.

notes.title: Advanced Excel Features
points: Conditional Formatting: Automatically highlighting cells based on rules like 'Value > 1,000,000'.
Data Validation: Restricting input to specific formats (e.g., ensuring a date is in the future).
Concatenate/TextJoin: Combining data from multiple cells (e.g., First Name + Last Name).
Absolute vs. Relative References: Using '$' to lock row/column values in copy-paste operations.

formulas.title: Excel Formula Example
formulas.explanation: A critical function for retrieving data from large account databases based on a specific ID or name.

formulas.title: Logical IF Function
formulas.explanation: Core logic used in bank interest calculations to check if a balance exceeds required minimums.

realworld.title: Business Reporting
realworld.description: Bankers use MS Excel to track loan disbursements, calculate monthly targets, and generate periodic performance reports.

realworld.title: Customer Comms
realworld.description: Banks use Word's Mail Merge feature to generate thousands of personalized interest rate notification letters in minutes.

notes.title: Physical components
points: Input Devices: Keyboard, Mouse, Scanner, MICR (Magnetic Ink Character Recognition).
Output Devices: Monitor, Printer (Inkjet, Laser, Dot Matrix), Plotter.
Internal Components: Motherboard, CPU, SMPS, CMOS battery.
Peripherals: External devices like UPS and Hubs.

notes.title: Ports & Connectors
points: USB (Universal Serial Bus): For connecting mice, keyboards, and drives.
HDMI/VGA: For connecting monitors and projectors.
Ethernet (RJ45): Physical port for high-speed wired internet connection.
Serial/Parallel Ports: Older standards often used for legacy banking passbook printers.

formulas.title: Resolution
formulas.explanation: Used to measure the quality of printed documents or the sensitivity of a mouse sensor.

formulas.title: Aspect Ratio
formulas.explanation: Proportional relationship between the width and height of a display screen.

realworld.title: Cheque Processing
realworld.description: Banks use MICR readers to quickly scan and verify the special ink on the bottom of cheques for clearing purposes.

realworld.title: Uninterrupted Service
realworld.description: Banking terminals are connected to online UPS (Uninterruptible Power Supply) to prevent data loss during sudden outages.

notes.title: Software Classification
points: System Software: Operating Systems, Device Drivers, Language Translators (Compiler, Interpreter).
Application Software: MS Office, Banking Software (like Finacle), Graphics software.
Utility Software: Anti-virus, File Compressors, Disk Defragmenter.
Open Source vs. Proprietary: Linux vs. Windows.

notes.title: Translators & Drivers
points: Compiler: Converts entire program to machine code at once (faster execution).
Interpreter: Converts code line-by-line (easier debugging).
Linker: Combines multiple object files into a single executable.
Device Drivers: Enable communication between the OS and physical hardware like printers.

formulas.title: Instruction Cycle
formulas.explanation: The fundamental process by which software instructions are executed by the CPU hardware.

formulas.title: Software Complexity
formulas.explanation: A structural metric used by software engineers to identify complicated and potentially buggy parts of banking code.

realworld.title: Cybersecurity
realworld.description: Banks deploy enterprise-grade utility software to protect all terminal endpoints from malware and ransomware attacks.

realworld.title: Banking Core
realworld.description: A bank's 'Finacle' or 'Flexcube' software is an industry-specific application that manages all ledger entries and account balances.

notes.title: OS Functions
points: Manages hardware, manages files, Provides GUI, and handles security and user access.
Types of OS: Multi-tasking, Multi-user, Real-time (RTOS), and Distributed OS.
Key Terms: Kernel (core of OS), Shell (interface), Booting (Cold and Warm).
File Systems: FAT32, NTFS (for Windows), ext4 (for Linux).

notes.title: Process & File Mgmt
points: Deadlock: A situation where two processes are waiting for each other to release resources, causing a freeze.
Paging: A memory management scheme that eliminates the need for contiguous allocation.
Segmentation: Dividing a computer's primary memory into segments based on logical categories.
Multithreading: Ability of an OS to run different parts of a program simultaneously.

formulas.title: Wait Time Logic
formulas.explanation: A metric used by OS schedulers to maximize the number of tasks completed in a given period.

formulas.title: Utilization %
formulas.explanation: Measures the efficiency of the CPU, indicating how much of its capacity is being useful.

realworld.title: ATM Operations
realworld.description: ATMs often run on specialized versions of operating systems that ensure immediate response to user input and hardware events (like cash dispensing).

realworld.title: Server Up-time
realworld.description: Unix-like operating systems enable bank servers to host thousands of simultaneous users without system crashes.

notes.title: Network Architecture
points: OSI Model: 7 layers (Physical, Data Link, Network, Transport, Session, Presentation, Application).
TCP/IP Model: 4 layers (Process, Host-to-Host, Internet, Network Access).
Network Types: PAN, LAN, MAN, WAN.
Topologies: Bus, Star, Ring, Mesh, Tree.

notes.title: IP Addressing & Data Path
points: IPv4 vs IPv6: 32-bit vs 128-bit addresses to overcome the shortage of web IDs.
Routers vs Switches: Routers connect networks (layer 3); Switches connect devices within a network (layer 2).
Bandwidth: The maximum data transfer rate of a network path.
Firewall Rules: White-listing specific bank URLs to prevent employees from visiting risky sites.

formulas.title: Connections
formulas.explanation: To calculate the number of physical links required in a fully connected mesh network with 'n' devices.

formulas.title: Bandwidth Calculation
formulas.explanation: Estimates the time required to sync bulk sensitive data across branch servers.

realworld.title: Inter-Branch Connect
realworld.description: Banks use Wide Area Networks (WAN) to link remote branches to the central data center, enabling real-time balance updates.

realworld.title: Guest Wi-Fi
realworld.description: Bank branches use Virtual LANs (VLANs) to separate customer Wi-Fi from internal secure networks to prevent hacking.

notes.title: Foundational Knowledge
points: Generations of Computers: 1st (Valves), 2nd (Transistors), 3rd (ICs), 4th (Microprocessors), 5th (AI).
Types: Mainframe (for big data), Supercomputer (speed), Mini/Micro (general use).
Data vs. Information: Raw facts vs. processed, meaningful results.
System Unit components and their roles in the data path.

notes.title: Logic & Number Systems
points: Number Conversions: Converting Binary to Decimal, Hexadecimal, and Octal.
Logic Gates: AND, OR, NOT, NAND, and NOR gates - the building blocks of circuits.
Firmware: Software programmed into specialized hardware (like BIOS).
User Account Control: Restricting user privileges to maintain system integrity.

formulas.title: Clock Speed
formulas.explanation: Measures the speed of the CPU in Hertz (Hz), commonly GigaHertz (GHz) today.

formulas.title: Binary Conversion
formulas.explanation: The mathematical method to convert a binary string into its decimal representation.

realworld.title: Enterprise Computing
realworld.description: Large banks still use Mainframe computers because of their unparalleled ability to handle massive volumes of simultaneous transactions securely.

realworld.title: Fraud Detection
realworld.description: Modern banks use Artificial Intelligence algorithms to detect unusual spending patterns and prevent credit card fraud.
